context: However, <a0_0>relatively few<a0_0/> organisations maintain computer systems with <b10_0>effective<b10_0/> detection systems, and fewer still have <b6_0>organised response mechanisms<b6_0/> in place. As result, as <a3_0><b11_0>Reuters<b11_0/><a3_0/> points out: "Companies for the first time report they are losing more through <b9_0><b13_0>electronic theft of data<b13_0/><b9_0/> than <a4_0><b7_0>physical stealing of assets<b7_0/><a4_0/>". The primary obstacle to effective eradication of cyber crime could be traced to excessive reliance on <a2_0><b5_0><b12_0>firewalls and other automated "detection" systems<b12_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/>. Yet it is basic evidence gathering by using <a1_0><b8_0><b14_0>packet capture appliances<b14_0/><b8_0/><a1_0/> that puts criminals behind bars.
